raw_text:
Celts savour Grand Slam prospect
 
 The Six Nations has heralded a new order in northern hemisphere rugby this year and Wales and Ireland rather than traditional big guns France and England face a potential Grand Slam play-off in three weeks' time.
 
 But before that game in Cardiff, Wales must get past Scotland at Murrayfield, while Ireland face the not insignificant task of a home fixture with the mercurial French. No-one knows what mood France will be in at Lansdowne Road on 12 March - sublime, as in the first half against Wales, or ridiculous, like in the same period against England at Twickenham. But how the mighty have fallen. England sat on rugby's summit 15 months ago as world champions and 2003 Grand Slam winners. But they have lost nine of their 14 matches since that heady night in Sydney. And they face the ignominy of what could amount to a Wooden Spoon play-off against Italy in a fortnight.
 
 England are enduring their worst run in the championship since captain Richard Hill was dumped in favour of Mike Harrison after three straight losses in 1987. Coach Andy Robinson, who took over from the successful Sir Clive Woodward in September, has lost a phalanx of World Cup stars. And he is enduring the toughest of teething problems in bedding down his own style with a new team. The same year that England ruled the roost, a woeful Wales lost all five matches in the Six Nations. And they won only two games, against Scotland and Italy, in 2004. Wales' most recent championship title was in 1994, and their last Grand Slam success came in 1978 in the era of Gareth Edwards, Phil Bennett, JPR Williams et al.
 
 But Welsh rugby fans remain on permanent tenterhooks for the blossoming of a new golden age. After several false dawns, coach Mike Ruddock may have come up with the team and philosophy to match expectations. The fresh verve is inspired by skipper Gareth Thomas, now out with a broken thumb, accurate kicking from either fly-half Stephen Jones or centre Gavin Henson, a rampant Martyn Williams leading the way up front, and exciting runners in the guise of Henson and Shane Williams. Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan and captain Brian O'Driscoll have got their side buzzing too, and they are close to shedding the "nearly-men" tag that has dogged them for the past few years. The men from the Emerald Isle have been Six Nations runners-up for the past two years, to France and England.
 
 But they have not won the title since 1985 and last clinched a Grand Slam in 1948. As for Scotland, they have struggled this decade and the 2004 Wooden Spoon "winners" have not been in the top two since they lifted the title in 1999. Italy continue the elusive search for their first Six Nations away win, and can still only account for the scalps of Scotland (twice) and Wales since joining the elite in 2000. Coach John Kirwan is a passionate and dedicated believer in the Azzurri, but is lacking in raw materials. And so to France. Brilliant one minute, inept the next. But the reigning champions could quite easily turn on the style in Dublin and end up winning the title through the back door. Ireland, though, have won three times in their last five meetings. Welsh romantics would probably prefer a glorious victory in the Celtic showdown to crown their Grand Slam. But given that Ireland have beaten Wales in four of their last five meetings, the Welsh legions are likely to be behind Les Bleus on 12 March.
llama3.2:1b: Wales and Ireland face potential Grand Slam play-off opponents in rugby's Six Nations tournament after defeating Scotland and France respectively.
Both teams' chances of winning the championship are uncertain due to recent performances and losses.
England, who were world champions and 2003 Grand Slam winners, have struggled since then and face a tough Wooden Spoon play-off against Italy.
llama3.2:3b: The Six Nations has seen a shift in power, with Wales and Ireland potentially facing France in a Grand Slam play-off.
England, once world champions, are struggling under new coach Andy Robinson, who has lost key players and faces a potential Wooden Spoon play-off against Italy.

Meanwhile, Wales' prospects have risen with a young and talented team led by captain Gareth Thomas, while Ireland's Eddie O'Sullivan is close to getting his side back on track after several years of nearly-missing out.
Scotland struggle, and Italy search for their first Six Nations away win, but France could easily turn the table against them.
gemma2:2b: Wales and Ireland are potential contenders for the Grand Slam this season, challenging France's dominance.
England is facing a difficult period with a string of losses and may face a Wooden Spoon play-off match, while Italy struggles to find their winning streak.
Wales' recent successes and Ireland's history as runners-up have fueled excitement within their respective fanbases.
Scotland continues to struggle in comparison to previous years, and France presents a volatile factor for the title race with unpredictable performances.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Wales and Ireland are facing potential Grand Slam play-offs in Cardiff, while England must overcome Scotland at Murrayfield, France is still searching for a win, and Ireland must beat Italy.
The title has been won by Wales since 1985 and last by Italy since 2000.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Six Nations rugby tournament sees Wales and Ireland potentially emerging from the group phase with a chance at a Grand Slam play-off against France within three weeks.
Despite England's recent struggles under Andy Robinson, including losing their World Cup stars, the Welsh team under Mike Ruddock is showing promise with standout performances.
France remains unpredictable but has shown potential to overturn the odds.
qwen2.5:3b: The Six Nations has seen a shift with potential Grand Slams up for grabs between teams like Wales and Ireland rather than traditional heavyweights France and England.
However, these sides face challenges ahead, including an uncertain performance from potentially fallen giants France.
Meanwhile, England's decline since winning the World Cup shows signs of continued struggle under new coach Andy Robinson.
In contrast, Welsh and Irish rugby is showing promising improvements with younger players and revived spirits among their teams.
Scotland remain a challenge despite recent poor form, while Italy have yet to win away in the championship.
France’s inconsistent play leaves them as potential Grand Slam contenders, though history suggests Ireland may come out on top against Wales in Cardiff.
opencoder:1.5b: The Six Nations has been hailed as a new order in northern hemisphere rugby this year.
The outcome is exciting and unpredictable for Wales and Ireland, with the potential for a Grand Slam play-off against France and England in three weeks' time.
However, before that game in Cardiff, Wales must face the French, who will be playing against Murrayfield.
No one knows what mood France will be in at Lansdowne Road on 12 March - it is sublime as in the first half of the game against Wales and for England at Twickenham.
They are enduring their worst run since they lost nine matches in Sydney in the same period against England, Italy and France.
England are enduring their tough runs from the past few years.
They won only two games, against Scotland and Italy, in 2004.
Welsh rugby fans remain on permanent tenterhooks for the blossoming of a new golden age after several false dawns.
After several false dawns, coach Mike Ruddock may have come up with the team and philosophy to match expectations.
The fresh verve is inspired by Gareth Thomas, who has been out with a broken thumb and accurate kicking from either fly-half Stephen Jones or centre Gavin Henson.
Ireland's most recent championship title was in 1994, and their last Grand Slam success came in 19.78 in the era of Gareth Edwards, Phil Bennett, JPR Williams et al.
However, England continue the elusive search for their first Six Nations away win, and can only account for the scalps of Scotland (twice) and Wales since joining the elite in 2,000 years.
England have won three times in their last five meetings.
Welsh romantics would probably prefer a glorious victory in the Celtic showdown to crown their Grand Slam.
But given that Ireland have beaten Wales in four of their last five meetings, the Welsh legions are likely to be behind Les Bleus on 12 March.
smollm:1.7b: The Celts savour Grand Slam prospect
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The Six Nations rugby season in 2005-2006 presents a promising chapter for Wales and Ireland as they hope to secure a Grand Slam playoff match against France or England at Cardiff.

This year, Wales will face Scotland before facing the crucial game, while Ireland will battle their home fixture with France, with expectations of a Wooden Spoon play-off against Italy in a fortnight.
Wales and Ireland have struggled since their past performances, with Wales finishing second to England in the 2004 Six Nations.
Ireland has had mixed results, securing two titles (1994 and 1978) and being a six-nation runner-up for the last two years.
They are currently "nearly-men" but have made strong progress this season.
England is a team on permanent tenterhooks, having endured one of their worst performances since Richard Hill was replaced by Mike Harrison.
The coach Andy Robinson faces challenges and has lost a number of top players, while Wales' recent dominance in the league is overshadowed by their poor performance against England.
In summary, Wales and Ireland are set to face intense competition, with both teams expected to perform at high levels this season.
Their future success will hinge on overcoming recent issues and delivering consistent results.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Six Nations has brought about a new order in northern hemisphere rugby and Ireland, England, France, and Scotland are currently competing for the Grand Slam.
Wales, on the other hand, is struggling to regain their former dominance and has been struggling recently with injuries to some key players.
Despite this, coach Andy Robinson has introduced a new team philosophy inspired by quick kicker Gareth Thomas and skillful runners in the guise of center Gavin Henson and fullback Shane Williams.
Ireland is also in good form, having won three matches in their last five against Wales and France, while Scotland struggled this decade with an elusive away win.
However, Italy's quest for their first Six Nations away win since joining the elite has been unsuccessful so far.
Meanwhile, France is currently in a glorioous victory mode in Ireland, but Welsh legions are expected to support Les Bleus on 12 March.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Six Nations has witnessed a new era for Northern Hemisphere rugby as France and Italy emerge as contenders, with both nations hoping to seize momentum in the coming weeks.
Meanwhile, Wales and Ireland face significant challenges in their quest for Grand Slam glory, as they prepare for key matches in Cardiff and Murrayfield respectively.
The Six Nations has also been marred by several controversies this year, with France's loss at the hands of England being especially notorious.
Despite these setbacks, there is a renewed sense of optimism among rugby fans as the 2006 season approaches.
phi:2.7b: The Six Nations championship has been dominated by Wales and Ireland, who may face a potential Grand Slam play-off in three weeks' time.
However, before that game, Wales must beat Scotland at Murrayfield while Ireland faces France.
The success of the big guns such as England and Italy remains to be seen.
Wales are hoping for a new golden age after several false dawns.

France and England face a potential play-off in three weeks' time.
But before that game in Cardiff, Wales must get past Scotland at Murrayfield, while Ireland face the not insignificant task of a home fixture with the mercurial French.
No-one knows what mood France will be in at Lansdowne Road on 12 March - sublime, as in the first half against Wales, or ridiculous, like in the same period against England at Twickenham.
But how the mighty have fallen.
England sat on rugby's summit 15 months ago as world champions and 2003 Grand Slam winners.
But they have lost nine of their 14 matches since that heady night in Sydney.
And they face the ignominy of what could amount to a Wooden Spoon play-off against Italy in a fortnight.
Wales' most recent championship title was in 1994, and their last Grand Slam success came in 1978 in the era of Gareth Edwards, Phil Bennett, JPR Williams et al.
But Welsh rugby fans remain on permanent tenterhooks for the blossoming of a new golden age.
After several false dawns, coach Mike Ruddock may have come up with the team and philosophy to match expectations.

The fresh verve is inspired by skipper Gareth Thomas, now out with a broken thumb, accurate kicking from either fly-half Stephen Jones or centre Gavin Henson, a rampant Martyn Williams leading the way up front, and exciting runners in the guise of Henson and Shane Williams.
Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan and captain Brian O'Driscoll have got their side buzzing too, and they are close to shedding the "nearly-men" tag that has dogged them for the past few years.
The men from the Emerald Isle have been Six Nations runners-up for the past two years, to France and England.
But they have not won the title since 1985 and last clinched a Grand Slam in 1948.
hermes3:3b: Wales and Ireland potentially face Grand Slams play-offs in Six Nations rugby.
Wales look for a new golden age with skipper Gareth Thomas, promising players like Henson, Williams etc.
England faces Wooden Spoon and their worst run since 1987; Wales last Grand Slam was in 1978, while Ireland's last came in 1948.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Wales and Ireland have a good chance of achieving a Grand Slam play-off in the Six Nations, with Wales facing Scotland before facing an uncertain France in their home fixture, while Ireland face French team in a crucial away match.
England has struggled in recent matches, losing nine out of their last 14 games, and may face a Wooden Spoon play-off against Italy.

Wales and Ireland have revived their teams with new coaches and captains, led by Gareth Thomas, Stephen Jones, Gavin Henson, and Shane Williams for Wales; Brian O'Driscoll and Eddie O'Sullivan for Ireland.
Despite strong performances, both Wales and Ireland may face tough battles to achieve a Grand Slam as they have faced France multiple times in the past few years with mixed results.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The Six Nations rugby tournament has seen a shift in dominance, with Wales and Ireland emerging as top contenders for a potential Grand Slam, rather than traditional powerhouses France and England.
Before their decisive clash in Cardiff, Wales must overcome Scotland, while Ireland faces an unpredictable French team.
England, once world champions, are struggling, having lost nine of their last 14 matches and facing a possible Wooden Spoon play-off against Italy.
Wales, after years of underperformance, are showing promise under coach Mike Ruddock, with key players like Gareth Thomas, Stephen Jones, and Shane Williams leading the charge.
Ireland, led by coach Eddie O'Sullivan and captain Brian O'Driscoll, are also in strong form but have not won the title since 1985.
Scotland and Italy continue to struggle, with Italy still seeking their first away win.
France remains inconsistent but could still claim the title.
Welsh fans hope for a Grand Slam, but given Ireland's recent dominance over them, they may find themselves supporting France in the crucial match on 12 March.
stablelm2:1.6b: Wales and Ireland face potential Grand Slam play-offs with France looming as a wildcard.
England's decline has led to a Wooden Spoon play-off against Italy; Wales and Ireland aim for Six Nations records.
Scotland aims for their first win since 1998, while Italy seeks an away victory.
France may surprise in Dublin if they turn on the style after struggling earlier in the tournament.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The Six Nations rugby tournament has shifted the power dynamics in northern hemisphere rugby this year, with Wales and Ireland emerging as contenders for a potential Grand Slam play-off against France in Cardiff.
Before this, England, previously world champions and 2003 Grand Slam winners, have suffered an unprecedented slump, losing nine of their 14 matches since their last victory in Sydney in 2003.
They face a Wooden Spoon play-off against Italy in two weeks.
Meanwhile, Wales, who haven't won the championship since 1978 and their last Grand Slam in 1948, are on the brink of a new golden era under coach Mike Ruddock.
Ireland, once Six Nations runners-up to France and England for two years running, have also shown significant improvement under Eddie O'Sullivan and captain Brian O'Driscoll.
Scotland struggled in 2004 as Wooden Spoon winners but have fared better since then.
Italy are still seeking their first Six Nations away victory, while France's inconsistent performance makes their home match against Ireland crucial for a potential title triumph.
